title-group.article-title: A Computer Network Approach to Pricing Mortgage-Backed Securities

abstract.p: Valuing complex financial instruments requires simulations of cash flow patterns in volatile interest rate environments. Because these simulations are computationally intensive, their use has thus far been limited to interday analyses and planning. The user and research communities have turned to computer systems with highly advanced architectures, such as parallel and vector supercomputers, in search of more performance. The search has largely ignored a significant pool of computational power that is already widely available in financial institutions--large networks of low-cost, general-purpose workstations. State-of-the-art processors with substantial memory and disk space are lightly loaded or even idle for large periods of time. Available software technology can harness these resources into an ensemble that delivers supercomputer performance without the capital costs or operating expenses of supercomputer machines. The pricing of mortgage-backed securities provides an example. Specifically, the MOrtgage Simulation and Evaluation System (MO.S.E.S.) developed at the HERMES Laboratory of the Wharton School can be adapted using available software to execute on a network of workstations, achieving performance levels typical of supercomputers. Furthermore, the system can be rapidly deployed on other, more traditional parallel architectures with no additional programming effort.
